captions.text:
How do we live authentically?
Since the dawn of philosophy,

thinkers have posed questions such as “Does
this plank exist?” or “Does God exist?”

But 20th century philosopher Martin Heidegger
thought that before questioning whether something

exists, we must first ask “what is the meaning
of being?”

In his notoriously difficult book
Being and Time, Heidegger introduced the concept

of the human being as Dasein. Dasein is that
being that stands back from everyday consciousness

and recognizes its own being. Dasein asks
the question: what does it mean to “be?”

At first, however, Dasein does not distinguish
himself from the world
around him. He is completely immersed in it, or what Heidegger calls “being-in-the-

world.” But how does this relate to authenticity?
Living authentically involves, in

part, Dasein’s understanding of itself as
something that exists- and potentially doesn’t

exist.
One way to think about it is like

this- we carry on with our everyday activities
out of habit, we do things but do not consciously

consider THAT we are doing them. For example,
a craftsman uses his hammer every day without

thinking of it as an object independent from
himself- until something goes wrong.

When the hammer breaks, I come to
look at it not as just an object in the world,

but as an object THAT exists separately from
myself.

This is one way that Dasein becomes aware
not only of THINGS not being,

but also the possibility of Dasein’s own
NOT BEING- that is, Death. Living with the

awareness of one’s own NOT-being is a crucial
element of living authentically.
because it has to do with what Heidegger calls my "Ownmost"
Think of it like this. Nobody else can die *my* death. I cannot share it with anyone.
It is mine, and no one elses.

The authentic Dasein is constantly
aware of MY existence as MY OWN- to be defined

by myself, and not others.
The inauthentic Dasein lives

lacking an awareness of its own existence.
When one’s everyday activities are lost

in the mindless grind of the “public,”and
allows one's self to be socially constructed,

authenticity is lost- one becomes lost in
the “they”.

But that’s not to say that one must isolate
one’s self in order to live

authentically.
Authentic living is more of an

attitude, an attitude towards confronting
one’s own mortality, seizing one’s existence,
And making it one's own

title: Are You Authentic? (Heidegger + River City Ransom) – 8-Bit Philosophy

comments.text:
Being In 8 Bit and Stuff.  Is it a difficult book?  Being and Time, 
Being-One-Self = Who is something I point out to Whovians a lot as the joke 
of Dr Who, Doctor of Being on Self.  Suggest that book as manual to the 
originating philosophy of the character that seems lost now.  Heidegger's 
Deism and Maslow's Self Actualization are similar but there is something 
more enjoyable about reading Being and Time.﻿

comments.author: james Last

comments.text:
The fallen Dasein does not realize his fallen-ness when witnessing objects 
ready-to-hand become present-at-hand, (Hammer Example) rather due to 
something Heidegger names, the call of conscience. Dasein deals with 
'guilt', not of actions, rather one of not owning up, taking responsibility 
of what is ownmost, this is built into the existential structure of 
Dasein's being. This guilt/ call of conscience (as anxiety did) exposes 
Dasein to his own being as finite. And Dasein as 'truth'/ unfolding/ 
disclosing. Understanding this call of conscience/ guilt represents a 
"conversion" in Dasein (Religious language deliberately used, reference 
Kierkegaard) what allows him to take a particular stance towards death; 
anticipatory resoluteness. This particular mode of being toward death of 
anticipatory resolute disclosedness is what Heidegger calls an authentic 
mode of being.﻿

comments.author: James Samsom

comments.text:
Great stuff.

I think it may be important to note that Heidegger, like many philosophers, 
never really completed his philosophy and often challenged assertions from 
his seminal early works later in life. Authenticity as presented here is 
much more attractive to a young person who hasn't built a life than to an 
adult who has. The balance between a purely authentic but isolated life and 
choosing to conform becomes more important.﻿

comments.text:
I think, therefore something exists (ether me or something that 
simulates/represents me). Thus, I think, therefore *at least 1 thing* 
exists.

However, with just 1 thing in the universe, movement nor change would be 
possible; there would be no way to distinguish any type of variety, there 
would be nothing else than simply *it* ; in order to have an information 
code that can represent things other than itself, through combination, the 
code must have at least 2 variants - the concept of Boolean data, or a 
binary system.  Thus, something else must exist! We have the *thing* , and 
the *something else* .

So, remaking that first statement:
*I think, thus something exists and at least something else also exists.*﻿

comments.author: Raggle Daggle

comments.text:
There is no question that we exist.
What perception of reality are you going to fill in the blanks with is what 
you really what to ask?

Whatever you fill in the blanks with will determine what you think you are. 
Choose wisely. Follow the cause and effect of your beliefs to the very end. 
Use the facts you can observe and or have already been proven to the best 
of ability, (there are facts by the way; if there were no facts then we 
wouldn't be texting on this electronic device because we would have no 
facts to use to manipulate matter into this state).

I suggest face the facts that nobody knows what life is, period. Then we 
can all start asking the right questions.

While we go on experiencing awareness in this complex micro-biological 
symbiotic state, let's be reasonable, stern but empathetic, and have grand 
intentions for the future forms of life to come.

Why you ask?

Every 10 years people discard of 90% of their physical matter and replace 
it with different matter. Those particles are recycled and used again in 
other complex life forms. We have no choice; this is what happens. Here is 
an analogy to make this one point more clear. Captain Kirk gets teleported 
from one place to another; in order to do this he is first destroyed, (he 
is now dead and that life form no longer exists). Now we take all those 
particles and put them back together. We now have created an entirely new 
form of life; this form of life doesn’t know the difference. The new life 
form is comprised of particles; those particles are what experiences 
awareness.

Even if you looked at the “human” as an individual; when you look hard 
enough, you will see mitochondria, (which have a separate DNA). 
Mitochondria produce the energy for our cells, without them we would never 
be in this form; we are in symbiosis on a cellular level. Down to the very 
fabric of our being and on the all scales of size in the entire universe so 
sort of give and take symbiosis can be observed.

The thing that makes you an individual is the lies you tell “yourself”. The 
concept of death having total lack of understanding has corrupted our 
thinking with fear. We fear death so we construct coping mechanisms. The 
soul and religion are some of them.

In nature plants eat the stars; we eat the plants and spread/fertilize the 
seeds, (when we die the human body breaks down into the nutrients that 
plants eat); bees pollinate the flowering plants, (without bees we die); 
birds fecal matter helps to keep soil of the forest fertile, (without the 
forest the nutrients of the soil degrades and we all die); without birds 
and the forest we all die; period. Facts! Not opinions! If you doubt it, go 
research it!

Best think very hard about what all this means; strive to understand the 
complexities of our environment/reality. Nothing is as simple as we would 
like and filling in the blanks is reckless. Reality is extremely complex; 
we must strive to understand the depths of this complexity. Without 
understanding we are reduced to children running with scissors.

Our perception of individualism is the biggest perceptional problem for 
humanity to overcome next. If we do not get our egos in check and shed our 
excessive individualism, the psychological damage will continue and destroy 
what we have built. Then it's back to a simple and more reactionary state 
of existence. Taking steps backwards doesn't seem logical.
 
 
 
 ﻿

comments.text:
Individualism: the distortion of humanities ability to see themselves as 
part of nature.

Perhaps this is a sign of a deeper problem. I think so at any rate. I can 
relate most problems in humanity to one root cause; peoples lack of 
connectivity to the biota of earth. Simplistic views of individuality; 
which is probably as close to the truth as the world being flat; for sure 
it’s akin to that analogy.

We once thought the Earth was flat.

We once saw ourselves as the center of the universe.

We still believe in god’s heaven and hell!!!? Ok whatever.

We also believe ourselves to be separate from nature and each other!!??

Some great thinker said people do the best they can with their level of 
awareness.

Well how aware of reality do you really think you are?

How much do you truly understand?

How great is the probability that you really understand your own 
observations?

Connectivity and tribalism: The self no longer exists? Individualism should 
be questioned in general. We are also addicted to the tribalism that the 
internet gives us. Perhaps this is more evidence that we're one massive 
complex life form; that craves to be connected to its other brain cells of 
the universe. I'm not sure; just saying that we should consider the 
possibility.

Has individualism gone too far? I say yes. We are as much of an individual 
as the hairs on your arm. Just like the hair on your arm you get different 
sensory information; due to your physical position in space and the cause 
and effect around you but you’re still part of the body.  We are the fruit 
on the end of the branch of the tree of life.

Now apply that to life forms on this planet as the sensory organs of the 
Earth. We are the hair follicles of the earth; or perhaps a little more 
complex; the eyes, ears, and brain cells of the universe.

I’m not saying that’s true and individualism is totally false. I’m saying 
everyone assumes we are individuals; under what facts? If you really 
examine the big picture; you can find evidence to say we part of all life; 
more so than we are individuals. You just have to look at the world with 
bigger and more complex scope of view. It’s not easy but its necessity for 
humanity to adopt these principles if we want to survive, be happy, and 
treat other life with respect.

If we had these views throughout history and education; we would never 
abuse a fellow life form in the ways we have and are right this minute.

I can relate all the roots to this problem from the perception of reality 
we are given by religion and creationism myth.
 
1. The concept of being created by god in his image; what is the affect on 
the mind? Well the mind then believes itself special and separate from 
nature and everything else. Hence individualism is born.  We see where that 
concept has utterly failed; with ease. Greed, hate, creation of borders and 
territory, (which creates war), and picking on the ugly kid at school, 
(focused on someone’s appearance rather than their ability or other true 
beauties).  All created by individualism.

2. The brainwash of children at an early age when they are very susceptible 
to that sort of conditioning. Those children then grow up with the 
psychological brain wash of automatically taking everything on faith; that 
comes from the points of authority; damaging to any society that needs to 
keep its business and government in check.

I also find it to be child abuse to lie to kids about something that big. 
Maybe tell them the whole god thing for the same ages that enjoy Santa, 
then, tell the kid the truth when they are ready; that we are all scared 
and nobody knows what life is.

Think about it; a child knows nothing, they look to an adult/parent to give 
them good information so they can better survive; teaching them to fill in 
the blanks when you really don't know is teaching them to worship opinions 
and make up imaginary friends instead of facing reality and their fears.

3. Another psychological effect. The concept of good and bad; heaven and 
hell; led to black and white. This black and white thinking model is the 
biggest problem we faced when trying to convince any person of any truth. 
They always look at it as right or wrong; black or white. When the reality 
is that it’s more of a grey area; there is no black and white. Things are 
almost never as simple as that thinking model.

 For example; nobody really knows what life is at all; period. Here is some 
actual science and blatantly logical facts for everyone to ask what it 
means.

Every 10 years people discard of 90% of their physical matter and replace 
it with different matter. Those particles are recycled and used again in 
other complex life forms. We have no choice; this is what happens. Here is 
an analogy to make this one point more clear. Captain Kirk gets teleported 
from one place to another; in order to do this he is first destroyed, (he 
is now dead and that life form no longer exists).

Now we take all those particles and put them back together. We now have 
created an entirely new form of life; this form of life doesn’t know the 
difference. The new life form is comprised of particles; those particles 
are what experiences awareness.

Even if you looked at the “human” as an individual; when you look hard 
enough, you will see mitochondria, (which have a separate DNA). 
Mitochondria produce the energy for our cells, without them we would never 
be in this form; we are in symbiosis on a cellular level. Down to the very 
fabric of our being and on the all scales of size in the entire universe so 
sort of give and take symbiosis can be observed.
T
he thing that makes you an individual is the lies you tell “yourself”. The 
concept of death having total lack of understanding has corrupted our 
thinking with fear. We fear death so we construct coping mechanisms. The 
soul and religion are some of them.

In nature plants eat the stars; we eat the plants and spread/fertilize the 
seeds, (when we die the human body breaks down into the nutrients that 
plants eat); bees pollinate the flowering plants, (without bees we die); 
birds fecal matter helps to keep soil of the forest fertile, (without the 
forest the nutrients of the soil degrades and we all die); without birds 
and the forest we all die; period. Facts! Not opinions! If you doubt it, go 
research it!

Best think very hard about what all this means; strive to understand the 
complexities of our environment/reality. Nothing is as simple as we would 
like and filling in the blanks is reckless. Reality is extremely complex; 
we must strive to understand the depths of this complexity. Without 
understanding we are reduced to children running with scissors.

Our perception of individualism is the biggest perceptional problem for 
humanity to overcome next. If we do not get our egos in check and shed our 
excessive individualism, the psychological damage will continue and destroy 
what we have built. Then it's back to a simple and more reactionary state 
of existence. Taking steps backwards doesn't seem logical.

comments.text:
I think that this whole authentic ideal is tied into the idea that the self 
is one thing and of highest value. Which always merits questioning. You 
might be labeled as a good person but then have to do something unthinkably 
evil in an extreme case of unusual circumstances then be immediately 
labeled "bad" and even become more well known for being bad. You might 
consider yourself more bad then you are because of low self esteem and then 
when exposed to extreme circumstances not be as bad as you were. Why 
couldn't it be yourself changes as you go along? 
Lets say a young man joins the army to gain honor and fame. He kills 
someone because his life is in danger and feels regret for his crimes 
devotes himself to charity. Is it really one guy with conflicting traits, 
or did his self change when he had a new set of challenges? Would it be 
inauthentic to accept that he is a New different person? Or is he being 
inauthentic not holding onto his first self. These are things I like to 
think about.﻿

comments.author: Andre Towers

comments.text:
Heidegger basically explained "Carpe Diem" (or a sort of YOLO for the 
uninformed) in a way that makes us independent from social acceptance. But 
one can't live without depending on another, so is Heidegger's theory 
flawed? I think not, as Heidegger's philosophy does not indicate TOTAL 
isolation from society. It simply suggest that independence can be 
valuable, as you don't depend on public opinion for your daily choices or 
rather "routine". In much simpler terms, you don't really care what people 
think about you whether good or bad. Thought I clarify for some people 
since some were questioning how this make sense and how it appliea to us. 
Thank you Wisecrack for a great video and more food for thought :)﻿

comments.text:
But many animals are not aware of their existence as individuals ans not 
knowing they are going to die. Does this mean they don't live 
authentically? ﻿
comments.author: Joseph M.

comments.text:
+Judiniho Alvarez Vulture's do not understand death nor is it likely to 
perceive itself as an individual it is purely reactionary and simplistic, 
very instinctual creature.

Self preservation is what they refer to it as and it is an instinct. Just 
because things don't want to be harmed and have an instinct to try to 
activate that, it doesn't mean that they have a concept of individualism.

The nervous system conveys message of pain, which all life forms 
experience, and then develop an instinct to avoid it.

The nervous system is comprised many smaller creatures that are all working 
together.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Joseph M. Sorry about that my brain works in a strange way.

The more simple the life form the more authentic. The more complex the life 
form the more potential for perceptional corruption and less authenticity.

Once a life form reaches the level of complexity that allows for 
imagination, we start to fill in the blanks. This leads to a lack of 
authenticity or a false perception of reality. Whereas a simpler creature 
just goes by instinct for the most part.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
Actually, many animals understand death. Like vultures waiting for you to 
die before they eat remains. Some animals wait by dying animals, to 
apparently ease their pain through death... They are aware of their 
existence as individuals, but for almost all other species except us, and 
maybe the animals we have taken under our safety, see it makes sense to 
thrive in some tight community - like ant colonies, herds etc. Although I 
admit some lack that understanding of their own existence maybe, but it is 
like us through childhood we lack sentience. A baby could crawl into a 
road, and be ran over. But with age and understanding, we can tell that is 
not such a good idea. Similarly a puppy could wander into the road, and 
some grown dogs still do. But most understand danger, and actively avoid it 
to preserve themselves.
comments.author: Judiniho Alvarez

comments.text: +Metaphysical Axiom right. But that didn't answer my question

comments.text:
We are all life forms.
We live in different states of complexity, which dictates the level of our 
awareness.
Most life forms do not have the same kind of sensory organs; exp. different 
brains.

Most of the more simple creatures are very reactionary and instinctual. Get 
thirsty, try stuff until the thirst goes away. Some things are learned 
though.

I call this wrong. Human being is shapd by opinions of others. That is what

comments.author: kosci55

comments.text:
Of course your opinion is one of many possibilities.

your genes are shared with every living thing on earth, the entire biota of 
Earth.

Your body's physical material is replaced over a 10 year period of time 
with new physical matter.

Caterpillar chrysalis butterfly. Then to infinity.

The universe is a snake eating its own tail much like our bioto earth.

There's cause and effect and what it is, and what that means. Opinions make 
no difference. Probability is probability. Possibility is possibility.

The only question your left to face is how to choose perception of reality, 
or why, to what reason, to what gains, to what failures?
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom I am not sure if I understand you correctly, but are 
you saying that by answering yes to your question if I'm being authentic I 
am making myself not authentic? 

But maybe you are right. In my original point I stated that one cannot be 
authentic if he grew up around other humans, because they have a certain 
influence. 

When I stated that I am individual, it was meant to answer your question 
about my religious parents. I had in mind something like "Doesn't matter 
who you are if you believe in god" no-personality type of thing. That is 
certainly not my case. I personally believe that every human is individual 
because of his memories and genes. But you are right on the tribal part, I 
think.
comments.author: kosci55

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom I am not sure if I understand you correctly, but are 
you saying that by answering yes to your question if I'm being authentic I

But maybe you are right. In my original point I stated that one cannot be

comments.author: kosci55

comments.text:
It's also been answered. We know that it is a bit of both. Ultimately it's 
all cause and effect. 

Genetics will dictate many attributes. You will take after either your 
mother or your father ultimately. You're innate attributes our genetic, 
your base intelligence, color of your eyes, among others.

Then the other half is learned. We call that half nurture. The debate is 
called nurture over nature.

So you know you're an individual huh? 

It's possible that you're an individual. That is one of several 
possibilities. Although, that isn't necessarily the truth. It may seem 
obvious but that's only because the nurture part of this equation has told 
you that you're an individual. The fact that you accepted without question 
shows me the lack of authenticity within your personality.

You can call yourself a choo choo train, that doesn't mean that you're 
correct.

There are actually many scientific facts that suggests we are not 
individuals. That is an over simplification; life is much more complicated.

It's actually more likely that we are tribal. Individualism is merely a 
negative effect on humanity. Even if you were to examine just your body, 
then you will find a mass of microbiological symbiosis. To me it's obvious 
that we are not individuals but I understand why the rest of the world 
seems to enjoy this concept.

Sadly this over simplification, fill in the blanks, lazy view has become 
detrimental to our survival.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom I think you missed my point. Kind of. If you have to 
ask, no, my parents are not religious at all and I haven't always followed 
what they told me. 

Of course I am ware that I am individual. As we all are. But that is not my 
point. My point here is that if I was raised in another city, country, 
maybe without one of my parents, with other friends and so on, I would be a 
different person. 

That was to illustrate my point. Are we really being authentic? Does the 
way your parents bring you up shapes your behavior more than genetics? Is 
being authentic even relevant here? The question is what makes you the 
person you are more. Is it genetics or enviroment you grow up in?¨

I am not first to raise that question, it has been around for a quite a 
long time.
comments.author: kosci55

comments.text:
Life forms are affected greatly by outside stimuli. Even genetics are 
affected by cause and effect of the other matter around us.

If you do nothing but follow what your parents say, then you're not being 
authentic; well at least you're probably not being authentic.

Your parents are from a time of lower scientific awareness and were raised 
on an ideology even further behind. The further away from your parents 
perception of reality the better off you will be.

Are your parents religious?

Did they teach you that you're an individual?
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
That's part of being-in-the-world. Our society, language, peers, etc are a 
part of who we are and give us the tools with which to understand the world 
and to express ourselves. 

As was said in the video, being "authentic" isn't about separating 
ourselves from others, but an attitude in which we embrace our existence 
(including the parts which involve others)

comments.text:
+Liz Lee When I said "genuine" I meant being honest with myself. I'd rather

comments.author: Sepulcher

comments.text:
You might want to ask yourself rather then being "Genuine" "Unique" or 
"Special", if you are being truthful. Living up to your potential or just 
finding a new way to conform to an impossible ideal.  Instead of conforming 
to an ideal image, you try to rebl for no reason. The weirdest thing about 
being one of a kind is how quick the human personality can change.  Would 
you be embracing something whole heartedly that can't exist in a few years? 
Are you a series of memory banks and a pro/con like dislike check list. Or 
does the human have intrinsic value? Is there something beyond what makes 
us genuine that exists that cannot be changed by society of the 
environment. To thine ownself be true.

comments.text:
The only problem with Martin Heidegger's ideas about Dasein is the degree 
to which we are able to be authentic. There is no true authenticity, and 
the most that Dasein can hope for, is to be aware that it is primarily a 
product of environment and society and that it is influenced or what is 
currently influencing it and why.﻿
